site_name: THOMAS J. OR NANCY C. CARLSON

citations.narrative:
Three 18 week old dachshunds are housed together in a single enclosure that does not provide them the minimum
amount of required floor space. The dachshunds each measure 22 inches from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail
and they are housed in an enclosure with a floor that is 24 inches x 48 inches. They would require a minimum of 2,352
square inches of floor space, and the enclosure they are in provides 1,152 square inches.
Dogs need adequate space to move around freely and perform normal behavior movements without being crowded or
unavoidably contacting other dogs.
Each dog housed in a primary enclosure (including weaned puppies) must be provided a minimum amount of floor space,
calculated as follows: Find the mathematical square of the sum of the length of the dog in inches (measured from the tip
of its nose to the base of its tail) plus 6 inches. The calculation is: (length of dog in inches + 6) x (length of dog in inches +
6) = required floor space in square inches. The dogs were moved to a larger enclosure that provides adequate floor
space.

There are no records of when vaccinations or parasite control treatments were given for most the 61 adult dogs in the
facility. The licensee says they routinely do these preventative measures for all the adult dogs at one time in early
January, but they have not documented it.
The provision of adequate adequate veterinary preventative care (as outlined in the facilities Program of Veterinary Care
and signed by the attending veterinarian) is critical to the maintenance of the health and wellbeing of the dogs and must
be documented. The facility must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for USDA
inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of
administration.
To be corrected by: June 22, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.6(c)(1)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Three 18 week old dachshunds are housed together in a single enclosure that does not provide them the minimum 
amount of required floor space. The dachshunds each measure 22 inches from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail 
and they are housed in an enclosure with a floor that is 24 inches x 48 inches. They would require a minimum of 2,352 
square inches of floor space, and the enclosure they are in provides 1,152 square inches. 
Dogs need adequate space to move around freely and perform normal behavior movements without being crowded or 
unavoidably contacting other dogs.  
Each dog housed in a primary enclosure (including weaned puppies) must be provided a minimum amount of floor space, 
calculated as follows: Find the mathematical square of the sum of the length of the dog in inches (measured from the tip 
of its nose to the base of its tail) plus 6 inches. The calculation is: (length of dog in inches + 6) x (length of dog in inches + 
6) = required floor space in square inches. The dogs were moved to a larger enclosure that provides adequate floor 
space. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
There are no records of when vaccinations or parasite control treatments were given for most the 61 adult dogs in the 
facility. The licensee says they routinely do these preventative measures for all the adult dogs at one time in early 
January, but they have not documented it. 
The provision of adequate adequate veterinary preventative care (as outlined in the facilities Program of Veterinary Care 
and signed by the attending veterinarian) is critical to the maintenance of the health and wellbeing of the dogs and must 
be documented. The facility must keep copies of medical records for dogs and make the records available for USDA 
inspection. These records must include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of 
administration.  
To be corrected by: June 22, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

n
